title: Issue forks
description: Drupal contributors may now collaborate using git branches and merge requests. Until this day, code collaboration on drupal.org featured uploading patch files.

title: Drupal 9.0 released
description: The first Drupal release with no new functionality - and that's great! Drupal 8 committed to adding functionality in a backwards compatible manner. Drupal 9 has the same functionality as Drupal 8.9, but without a lot of backward compatibility code. This approach balances easy major version major upgrades with a lean codebase. https://celebratedrupal.org/ centralized our virtual parties, as this happened during the dark days of Covid-19.

title: Drupal 8.0 released
description: Five years in the making, Drupal 8 embraced OO and Symfony, and discarded most of its legacy bootstrap. Config, Entity API, Twig, and Accessibility are the talk at the many release parties. And the pies.

title: Australian government standardizes on Drupal.
description: govCMS embodies Drupal's popularity with governments all over the world.

title: SA-CORE-2014-005 - Drupal core - SQL injection
description: Many thousands of Drupal sites are compromised by Drupal core's first major security vulnerability.

title: Core Office Hours and Drupalcon Mentoring
description: xjm and catch provide core office hours on IRC 12 hours apart, providing global coverage. This generous spirit soon manifests at Drupalcon Denver as Core Mentoring, where newbies are guided up the contribution ladder.

title: Drupal 7.0 released
description: More than 250 parties in over 90 countries were held to celebrate this great release. Drupal 7 is still the most popular Drupal release, featuring the Seven theme, designed by Mark Boulton and Leisa Reichelt.

title: Drupal development moves from CVS to Git
description: More than 250 parties in over 90 countries were held to celebrate this great release. Drupal 7 is still the most popular Drupal release.

title: Certified to Rock web service launches
description: Certified To Rock is a new form of certification built to match the unique nature of the Drupal community. Give back more, and your score rises.

title: Drush 3 is released
description: Drush is no longer a module, leading to lots of functionality and popularity. Drush becomes the de facto command line tool for Drupal.

title: Drupal 6.0 released
description: This release features a rewritten menu system, and an Update Status module which prompts admins to update their modules, especially after a security release.

title: Sun Microsystems bails out drupal.org
description: Drupal.org becomes too popular for its home grown web hosting, and starts throwing errors regularly. Sun Microsystems donates its servers and restores stability to our home.

title: Acquia is announced to the world
description: Acquia, a startup by Dries Buytaert and Jay Batson, announces its intention to offer commercial support and hosting for Drupal. Acquia continues to be the largest sponsor of Drupal development, and its largest web hosting platform.

title: Drupal 5.0 is released
description: This release incorporates jQuery, a young open source project. Drupal's support helps jQuery gain attention and then it rises to huge popularity. This release introduces install profiles and a web based installer.

title: Views module is released
description: Earl Miles introduces Views, a query builder and list builder UI. Along with CCK, these form the early beating heart of Drupal. Views graduates into Drupal core with D8.

title: Drupal VZW formed in Europe.
description: Drupal's governance formalizes from BDFL to a non-profit model. Led by Jacob Redding, VZW is initially a money manager only. Drupal VZW transforms to the Drupal Association in 2011 and becomes more prominent in promoting Drupal.

title: Drupal 4.7 is released with a Form API.
description: The new Form API by Adrian Rossouw strengthens Drupal's secure-by-default approach. XSS protections, validation of choices, and only processing POST data that was actually on the form.

title: groups.drupal.org is launched
description: Moshe Weitzman introduced this portal for local user groups to build a community. Groups helped the Drupal community grow tighter, and helped newbies climb its learning curve. Later led by joshk, greggles, and ezra-g.

title: Lullabot podcast is launched
description: This podcast, founded by Jeff Robbins, still runs today. This marks a growth in the marketing and communication of Drupal.

title: 'Building Online Communities' is published
description: Robert Douglass authors the first Drupal book, recognizing a growing demand for Drupal education.

title: Drupal security team is formed
description: This volunteer team is first led by chx. The team dutifully protects Drupal core and all the contrib modules that opt into its coverage. Future leaders would be Heine, greggles, and mlhess.

title: First Drupalcon held in Antwerp.
description: Drupal enthusiasts meet in person for the first time. Amazingly, 45 people fly to Antwerp from all over the globe. The most important discussion is led by JonBob, about a new Content Construction Kit (CCK). This eventually became the Field API under the leadership of yched and KarenS.

title: Drupalers build Deanspace, a semi-official presence for USA presidential candidate Howard Dean.
description: This was a milestone in the rise of the Internet for political campaigns and grassroots initiatives. It also kicked off a long love affair between Drupal and non-profits.

title: Drupal 4.0 is released, with a new taxonomy module.
description: Taxonomy module, written by Marco Molinari. Marco wrote it because he needed a way to group forums into categories. Drupal's rich taxonomy system foreshadows what will be popularly known as tags/labels.

title: Drupal 3.0 is released.
description: 3.0 major had a whopping 6 month development cycle. Nodes are introduced as a building block for content. They can be specialized into many content types.

title: Druplicon is introduced
description: Drupal's famous logo, featuring infinity eyes and remixed into thousands of variants, is introduced by Steven Wittens and Kristjan Jansen.

title: Drupal 2.0 is released
description: A mere 2 months after 1.0, Drupal ships 2.0. Backward compatibility was not yet a concern. The translation system is introduced, with its brilliantly simple t() function.

title: Drupal 1.0 is released
description: Dries Buytaert shares the initial release of his 'dormitory bulletin board'. It includes 18 files that are called modules. It features a hook system where modules interact with each other and the core framework. On this very day, Wikipedia is also born. Had that happened 6 months later, it would probably be a Drupal site!.
